Introduction

Monica Seles is a former world No 1 professional tennis player who retired in 2008 after earning a small fortune from the sport.

While she may no longer play, Seles continues to grow her wealth as a spokesperson for Shire Pharmaceuticals.

As of January 2024, Monica Selesâ net worth is estimated to be $50 Million.

Monica Seles Facts

Monica Seles began playing tennis when she was five in 1978.

In 1985, Seles won the Junior Orange Bowl tournament when she was 11.

Seles turned professional when she was 15 in 1989 and won the French Open a year later as the youngest player to ever claim the title.

In 1996, after winning her fourth Australian Open, Seles made a guest appearance on the sitcom The Nanny.

Seles was named one of the 30 Legends of Womenâs Tennis: Past, Present, and Future, in 2011 by Time.

Early Life

Monica Seles was born December 2, 1973, in Novi Sad, SFR Yugoslavia (now Serbia), to an ethnic Hungarian family.

Her parents, Ester and Karolj, supported her interest in tennis from a young age, and her father even served as her first coach.

In 1985, when she was 11, Monica won the Junior Orange Bowl tournament in Miami, Florida, and caught the attention of tennis coach Nick Bollettieri, who encouraged her to enroll at his tennis academy.

Seles and her brother moved to the United States in 1986, and Monica trained for two years at Bollettieriâs, and under his tutelage, Monica won her first professional tournament as an amateur in 1988.

Career

Monica Seles officially started her professional tennis career in 1990, and she quickly ended up on a 36-match winning streak, claiming victory in six consecutive tournaments.

Seles then won her first Grand Slam singles title at the French Open, facing off against then-No. 1 player Steffi Graf to become the youngest-ever French Open singles champion at the age of 16.

In 1991, Seles once again started dominating womenâs tennis tour events, winning the Australian Open, the French Open, and the US Open, titles she successfully defended the following season.

Unfortunately, things would take a turn for the worse in 1993, when, after defeating Steffi Graf once more at the Australian Open, Seles was stabbed during the quarterfinal match at the Citizen Cup in Hamburg, Germany.

During this match, a man named Gunter Parche stabbed Seles with a boning knife between her shoulder blades in an attempt to end her tennis career.

Parche was allegedly a huge fan of Graf, and due to Seles having beaten her, he was attempting to take her out of the game permanently.

While her physical injuries healed in several weeks, it took Seles more than two years to start playing competitive tennis again.

After becoming a US citizen in 1994, Seles returned to the court in 1995, and the WTA president proposed that she be reinstated as the joint number one player alongside Graf.

Seles won her first comeback tournament at the Canadian Open, followed closely by the US Open, and her fourth Australian Open in 1996.

However, after this point, she never won another Grand Slam but did defeat Venus Williams and Lindsey Davenport during her final tour before retiring in 2003.

During her career, Monica Seles earned $14,891,762 in prize money.

In the early 90s, Seles signed a $4 million endorsement deal with Fila to promote their tennis apparel.

Seles wore apparel and used equipment from Yonex in the 2000s, though the amount she earned for the endorsement is unknown.

In 2009, Seles published her memoir Getting A Grip: On My Body, My Mind, My Self, earning her additional income.

As of 2015, Seles has served as a paid spokesperson for Shire Pharmaceuticals, promoting their binge eating disorder medication.

Monica Seles has earned an impressive amount of money, and her net worth is only continuing to grow even decades after her retirement.

Personal Life

Monica Seles married businessman Tom Golisano after becoming engaged in 2014, and while Tom has a daughter Amy from a prior marriage, the couple has no children of their own.

In 2009, Seles released her memoir Getting A Grip: On My Body, My Mind, My Self, which talks about her battle with depression and binge eating disorder after her stabbing attack and her fatherâs cancer diagnosis.

Due to her struggles, Seles has become a spokesperson for Shire Pharmaceuticals, a company that made the first drug approved by the FDA to help treat binge eating disorder.

On social media, Monica is active on her official Instagram account and her official Twitter account, where she posts about tennis and things that inspire her.

Monica Seles has won many titles and awards as a professional tennis player, many of which have helped distinguish her from other players.

While all of her achievements are notable, some have impacted her career more than others.

In 1990, Seles became the youngest-ever French Open champion when she won at the age of 16.

Monica Seles won three more Grand Slam Singles titles in 1991, including the Australian Open, the US Open, and the French Open.

In 1992, Seles won two more Grand Slam singles titles, this time at the French Open and Australian Open.

Seles won the Australian Open for the fourth time in 1996.

In 2009, Monica Seles was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

Monica Seles may not be as widely known as Andre Agassi, but she certainly has won an astonishing number of titles in a very short amount of time.

With an asking price of $1.4 million, her Sarasota estate boasts 5,871 sqft of living space and grand French doors that open out into a massive pool area.

Situated next to the Laurel Oak Country Club, this home blends Mediterranean and Classical styles and naturally comes with a full-sized tennis court.

While there is no information on where she has since moved, in interviews, she has reported downsizing and leaving the Sarasota area.
